div1.p: 1078 INRE: PETITION of JAMES P. LAVIN & SISTER M. ANGELIQUE of the HOUSE of the GOOD SHEPARD for WRIT of CERTORIARI
1078 INRE: PETITION of JAMES P. LAVIN & SISTER M. ANGELIQUE of the HOUSE of the GOOD SHEPARD for WRIT of CERTORIARI
Reproduced at the National Archives at Seattle
(Action to Remove a Habeas Corpus Case to US Circuit Court)
IN THE UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Petition of James P. Lavin, Immigrant Inspector and Sister Superior of the House of the Good Shepherd, for a Writ of Certiorari} No. Petition.
To the Hon. Cornelius H. Hanford, Judge of the above entitled Court for the District of Washington-:
Comes now James P. Levin and Sister M. Anquelique, by Edward E. Crushman, Assistant United States Attorney, and respectfully ahows the Court:
I.

That prior to the commencement of the suit hereinafter mentioned, the said James P. Lavin was, and still is an revenue officer in the Tresury Department, to-wit, an Immigrant Inspector, for the District of Puget Sound Collection District; that hertofore,in the discharge of his duties as such officer, on the 9th day of Febuary, 1903, he temporarily removed from the "Rosalis" a steuse ship, upon its arrival in Seattle, form the foreign port of Victoria, Youve Le Fevre, Marie Le Fevre and Georgette Normand, for the purpose of determining and investigating whether they were immigrants properly entitled to enter the United States; that thereafter, a Board of Inquiry was convened of the Tresury officials and Revenue officers according to law and the regulations of the Tresury Department, to investigate and determine the leigibility of the above named immigrants to land and enter the United States that upon such investigation, it was found and determined that said immigrants had within one year prior therto been imported into the United States, at the port of New York, from France, for puposes of prostitution. It was further found and determined that each one of them was liable to become a public charge. It was further found that they had
immediatly prior to being taken from said vessel for such purpose by your petitioner, left the United States and gone to Victoria, from which place they were returning to the United States; that upon this state of facts it was found and determined that they were not lawfully entitled to be in or enter the United States, and that they should be deported and returned to the country from whence they came; that said matter was held under advisement by the Tresury Department and said officers, pending a determination and order as to whether they should be deported to Victoria in the Province of Canada or the Republic of France, and that pending such determination your petitioner, James P. Lavin, as such officer, was and still is detaining and restraining of liberty each of said immigrants above named By express & diction of the section of the and as they are women, said petitioner has delegated the office of their detention and restraint to your petitioner Sister M. Angelique, and that she has been and is so restraining them of their liberty, acting under and by authority of your petitioner, James P. Lavin. That heretofore, to-wit, on the 13th day of Febuary, 1903, in the Superior Court of the State of Washington for the County of King, an action and suit is was commenced on the part of saidx immigrants, Yourve Le Fevre, Marie Le Fevre and Georgette Normand, against your petitioner, Sister M. Angelique, so acting as aforesaid, under color of her aforsaid office, by authority of the laws of the United States and the regulations of the Tresury Department and and dircetin oryour petitioner James P. Lavin.That your petitioer, Sister M. Angelique, has been served with proces, to-wit, a writ of habeas corpus, in said suit, entitled, "In the Matter of the Application of Yuonne Le Fefre, Mari Le Fevre and Georgette Normad," and being numbered 38028 in said Court; that there has not been as yet any trial or final hearing of said suit. Your petitioners therefore praythat in persuance of the laws of the United States that the said suit so commenced in the said Superior Court of the State of Washingotn for the County of King may be removed therefrom
into this Honorable Court for trial, and therupon proceed as a cause originally commenced in the same, and that a writ of certiorari in this behalf issue from this Honorable Court to the said Superior Court of the State of Washington for the Couty of King.
Edward E Cushinw Assistant United States Attorney
United Statesof America District of Washington} SS.
James P. Lavin, being first duly sworn, on oath deposes and says: That he is the petitioner above named, and the matters hereinabove set forth in said petition are true in substance and in fact.
James P. Lawin
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 13 day of Febuary, 1903.
C.H. Hauford U.S. Disthict Judge

I, EdwardE. Cushman, Assistant United States Attorney, herby certify that as a counsel for the petitioners I have examined the proceedin the State Courttherin mentioned, and carefullyinquired into all matters set forth in the said petiion, and belive them to be true.
Edward E Cushinw Assistant United States Attorney
Due and full service of within acknowledge this day of, 189 Attorney for
FORM NO.499 NO.1078
IN THE COURT OF THE UNITES STATES FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON Northern Division.
THE UNITED STATES VS. por the petiion of Lavin et al for Gestionari
Petition
FILED IN THE U.S. Circuit Court DIST. OF WASHINGTON FEB 14 1903 A.REEVES AVRES, Clerk HMS Statishem Dep.
WILSON R. GAY, UNITED STATES ATTORNEY, SEATTLE, WASHINGTON
